reviewText:
I rarely write reviews, but I MUST contribute here.

Where to begin! Well... I’ve probably put in over 1000 hours of play into this glorious gem over the years. Incredibly detailed slider control over just about every relevant aspect of a country. You can micro-manage just about everything.  Such as, determining exactly which natural resources to exploit, how much money goes into building infrastructure, and which religion you want to convert your population too. Not a big fan of micromanagement? No problem! let the AI handle the areas you don’t want to bother with. Every decision matters and can have huge consequences. Take control over military research, including nuclear arsenals, naval, and land. Battles on land and sea have neat little animation scenes.

Nuclear conflicts are VERY satisfying. Reminds me fondly of the War Games movie in the 90s.

The game is a bit dated now, but still looks and feels nice on a new PC. Unfortunately does not support high resolutions but, once you get past this, it’s worth every penny and every minute in playtime.

There is really something quite satisfying about turning Gaza Strip and the West Bank into a global superpower! Or perhaps you would like to nuke Canada? Then this is for you.

I highly reccomend this! I love RTS strategy games and this one is quite interesting. I like the game for It's economic system and how the AI Doesn't completely fail in the economic side, unlike Supreme Ruler where the AI builds nothing but Tanks, jets, naval stuff, ect ect, this is quite fun. I have already put 44 hours into the game and in that amount of time, i managed to turn county's like the Congo and Israel into superpowers. It's not all about agression in this game, it's about getting on everyones good side. You can't just simply take a random country and just build tons of units and destroy the world. It takes time and i love the way it does it. You have to sometimes depend on other country's for aid and you have to work your way up bit by bit untill you can actually annex something.


I love how the resources work, I mean, you don't have to manage resources all the time. You can get that all privitised and let your people expand it. That doesn't work all the time, you need to put some money into it so you can help your resources grow and the people will carry that duty on. Let's say Canada was the leader in Dairy production and you take that place, Canada will start to hate you and I love how it works.

Nukes, oh how I love them. They are not too over-powered, but yes they do pack a punch in this game. Nukes are quite cheap, depending on what nation you play as,but they take a long time to build and are quite expensive to maintain them. In packs, nukes can destroy populations and damage your enemy's resources heavily and turn military's to dust. Think before you use nukes, because using nukes will devistate your relations with other country's and if you use nukes in very small packs... Well, you will be better off throwing toothpicks at your enemy.

Here's where it gets bad. This game wasn't really made for Windows 7 or 8 and so it tends to crash a little bit. There are bugs in the game where some country's are nothing but luck to try and set up for becoming a superpower. Like the Democratic Republic of Congo, Rebels and some others. There's also a bug where you can't take certain land and so on. The game really does have some downfalls, sometimes relations tend to mess up. I got nuked by Russia and instead of people hating Russia, they started to hate me more. I don't understand this much, but it doesn't matter as long as you have a much more powerful military then your enemy's.


Is it worth the price considering the bugs? YES! You might get annoyed from the bugs, but indeed it's a fun game. Very easy to get used to and you will always find new ways to beoming powers. If it's from economic domination to just pure agression.

In this game you control one of over 150 countries; you manage their politics, economy, and military while dealing with debt, invasion, terrorism, natural disasters, and nuclear annihilation. Politics allow you to create treaties, change laws, and change your government (for instance democracy to communism). In your economy you will first have to get your country out of debt, then you have to manage your budget, inflation, interest, income tax, resource production, financial aid and agreements, and trade. Finally, military; your military can be either your life saver or your demise depending on your economy and diplomatic relations. In your military you can build, buy, sell, and deploy troops and vehicles. Besides that you can design your own units and research more technology for better stats on your designed units. If you are have a problem with another country why not strike them with your entire nuclear arsenal or send covert ops into their country and wreak havoc on their product and economy.

But this game isn't perfect. The games multiplayer doesn't run unless you open unsecure ports on your router. Your military can't invade a country unless your navy is 750 km away from your enemy’s shore, but if they have even a single boat within 1500 km of your navy you can't invade and occasionally the enemies ships don’t appear and you can't make a land invasion, which is beyond frustrating. But besides that I haven't run into to many other problems.
So is this game worth your $10? Yes. Would I recommend you wait until a sale? Not necessarily, it would be better if you did but this game is worth the full price. I've played this game for roughly 14 hours and t has become one of my favorites.

Bwee. This be similar to the grand strategy titles made by Paradox, except it is set in the present day and has no real time limit. Like those Paradox games, you can pick any country you choose and you more or less choose your own objectives. Unlike the Paradox games however, SP2 is chiefly a multiplayer game since the AI isn't very good and either brings countries to ruin or become completely outclassed by player-controlled countries to such a degree that there is little real challenge in solo games. Therefore if you are no fan of multiplayer, I would probably avoid this game.

When I first bought this game I was expecting something along the lines of DEFCON. I guess I got that, with a touch of civilization (minus the turn base), and ultimate control over diplomacy/markets.

This game is interesting to say the least, and was worth the buy ON SALE. This game as stated previous, gives you a world map (or the Earth in 3D) and you are allowed to choose a nation. With this nation you can build up your military, work your political magic, and look after your monetary situation. The military tab you are allowed to build anything that walks to anything that treads water to anything that may fly in the air. You can also customize vehicles which is a brilliant perk. In this tab is also covert military actions which allow you to manipulate political structures around the planet, and there is also a nuclear launch missile control available as well. Onto the 2nd tab which is the political station, one can choose whether they want to be fascist, communist, socialist or whatever. You also get to decide internal laws such as same-sex marriage and can limit how many kids a family can have. The diverse control the game lets you take into your hands is amazing. Some would say it's better left to the computer (which you can have) and some say it's better to micro manage (which you can choose to have as well)! I like the fact you are given the chance to choose what you want. Within the third tab which is the monetary settings, you can literally choose what you want to fund down to the level. Want to enhance education? Go ahead? Want to fund the military, screw it and do it! You can build more nukes if you'd like, or heck start getting covert warfare going by hiring some spies and sending them to other countries. And yes, nuking is oddly satisfying but really can screw up your political reputation. What is another cool feature is that you can watch your units fight the opposing side in real time (double left click on the battle to see).

Another interesting feature is that anywhere in the world you can right click and do quick treaties, such as alliances, common markets, weapon trade (or even embargo), research partners (and a lot more choices - you can even annex countries).

BUT.... (DEVS PAY ATTENTION HERE)!

The only few complaints I have is that you are not able to use the keyboard to quickly select which countries are in for what treaties, and can get extremely annoying using the mouse to select EVERYTHING (especially on the menus). Another complaint is that some countries are literally impossible to select. Even if you right click and attempt to do a quick treaty, sometimes if you try clicking on Israel you'll get Palestine. Same thing with Chile and Argentina.


Overall good game. Would be even more intense if they let you control the units when you can watch them fight. I would give this game an 8 if it was something that was truly unique to it's genre. Even though it didn't hit an 8, I would recommend buying on sale and playing!

7.65/10

Ricks Review

Summary:

Gameplay: 9/10 - Simple and complex political-combat-economic action which is realistic yet playable.

Combat: 8/10 - Very basic combat mechanics which require the construction of units, from Land, Sea, Air and Infantry. Many unit types are customizable for better battle performance and outcomes for the selected state. However in battle the player can not perform direct actions in the battle screen and is mearly the observer to the battle.

Politics: 9/10 - Limited in political details compared to games like Ruler of Nations and Masters of the Universe. But the game provides very indepth fields around the countries language and religious demographics, laws and government types. Although little is made in the changing of demographics, laws and governments except from saying Yes, No or Maybe. It does allow for a detailed and easy way for you to create your nation.

Economics: 9/10 - Amazing, indepth field of economics which allows the player to experience how the economics of any nation works. Through trading, diplomacy and domestic taxes, you can influence how your economy sways. Managing the budget can be tricky and challenging in various states, it is exciting and sometimes thrilling to compare various strategies and tactics which can improve the states economy.

Audio: 9/10 - Dynamic music to the situation, losing, winning and nuclear war are the main music types.

UI: 5/10 - Beautiful UI for the game type, however can be a bit quirky in situations. Where the movement of troops can be difficult and unpredictable where the units move several miles from the intended location.

Technical Side: 7/10 - Editor fails in stability and many stability and technical issues arise in the main game. Sometimes with many players experiencing game crashing on high-spec scenarios like nuclear war, dramatic economic changes or huge wars.

Moddability: 6/10 - Various mod types are available from historical scenarios to gameplay changes/additions to some fantasy and hypothetical scenarios, you can experience a game where Hitler wins or Communism is supreme. However the poor score is detailed because of its poor modding methods and editor, with its poor technical stability on modern computers and the extent of the moddability to scenarios only, it can limit potential and the lifespan of the game.

Community: 5/10 - Although this is not directly affected by the game, there is a large community atlarge in this game. However do expect a lot of bitter members which vary.

Servers & multiplayer: 2/10 - I honestly enjoy Roleplaying servers and messing around with servers. But it is so difficult and awkward to start a server, it is not worth the trouble. And starting a public server risks potential hackers, trolls and generally unwanted visitors. Although you can enforce passwords and friends only, those threats can exist still.

Main Points:

This game was made back in 2004, making the technology behind the game pretty old compared to modern standards, but with the games potential it proves superior among many other titles. But before considering buying the game, make sure to get into contact with other players to compare specs and computer technology to make sure the game will work on your machine.

Great Gameplay for a Political Simulation game which extends to Combat, Politics and Economy which can diversify depending on the nation you play as.

Amazing dynamic audio which changes depending on the current situation of your state or the global situation.

Stability can be poor on modern computers and the modding editor will not work on Windows 8.

Servers can be hard to set up and not advisable for quick games with friends.

Improvements:

Improve upon the modding capabilities to allow for modern computers to be accepting to the capability. Meaning modern computers can use the editor or an alternative means to mod the game. And making sure the player can mod anything in the game, from scenario to UI to menus.

Improve the servers by making sure a anti-cheat/hack system is installed and allowing for every player to create their own servers with players capable of joining.

reviewText:
It should first be noted that this game is ten years old, but still manages to perform and satisfy excellently.

Superpower 2 allows the player to take on the role of any nation that exists in 2001 (Yes, even Vatican City/The Holy See) and guide it on its path to become a world superpower. It styles itself as a geopolitical simulator, and that is exactly what it is, although it plays more like a grand strategy game akin to Europa Universalis IV or Hearts of Iron III or a mixture of every Paradox Interactive grand strategy game ever made (although it should be noted that one cannot simply assume the role of a dynasty or a character like in Crusader Kings II). It has a very fleshed out diplomacy, military, economic and politics system, and one can even create organisations like NATO or the UN through a treaty system. It is also possible for said treaties to collapse (In one game played hours before this review was written as Britain, NATO collapsed after America withdrew). The AI is very interesting and games are random (in the aforementioned game Pakistan ended up nuking India and invading, for example).

The one problem I have with this game is that there is a constant runtime error crash as of a recent update (I believe), and I am hoping that said crash will be fixed or a workaround found. I also want to congratulate Nordic Games on getting this great game on Steam.

All-in-all, I would recommend this game to anyone who has the money - it's an excellent purchase.

reviewText:
I'm telling you this. (No **** sherlock.)

Superpower 2 is unique. It has deep geographical technology which makes you zoom into the planet Earth to the point of seeing pixelated highways. While that may not be as cool as it sounds, look at the geography around it. Cool huh? But I am going to focus on the more 'economic' side of this game.

SP2 goes in deep with the economic system of the country you picked, and the free will to change your country's market from state controlled, to mixed, to free market, which is pretty awesome considering you can almost take control of 6 sectors and either import or export the amount of the resource you have. Most games don't have such in-depth-ness-ness. You can adjust the spending of specific areas such as health care, education, infrastracture, environment, propaganda (If you plan to be a very, very evil country with a brainwashed populace.), and et cetera. You can adjust your interest levels and see how inflation is going in your country, and adjust the personal tax income to whatever you wish to get the most dough out of it, but it will always result in the cold shoulder of your populace, so be careful when you want to go over 60%.

If you like to focus on the political aspects of this game, there isn't really much for you other than either legalizing/illegalizing a few dilemmas such as freedom of demonstration, freedom of speech, same-sex marriage, woman suffrage, polygamy, etc. But there are also the religions and languages, which you can either allow (Meh reaction from the populace in this religion/language), outlaw (I DON'T WANT THIS LEADER ANYMORE! reaction), or officialize (LEADER 4 LIFE! reaction). You can also participate and make various treaties, where it is also possible for you to play as Turkey and join the European Union with the approval of the countries inside the treaty.

You don't like economic or political but the more military aspects of this game? Well then. NUKES! Yes. Who does not like nukes? I do like nukes. And so do you, probably. You can research military technology to make more military designs such as fighter aircraft, attack aircraft, tanks, bombers, infantry vehicles, artillery guns, and so on and so forth. There is also a ranking system that determines how strong you are compared to other nations, which is influenced by your technological prowess, which ranges from 1 to 10. If you plan to dominate the world with the US, best to start with a lvl. 10 technological level.

And the most important thing?: There is multiplayer. FRIKKIN MULTIPLAYER!

I would definitely recommend this game to anyone with a taste for taking control of a country and changing it around completely. The sky and the autarky bug are the limits! Maybe.

10/10

reviewText:
I recently purchased SuperPower 2 to play with friends, and right away I loved it. The  game seems to offer endless possibilities (especially when you're playing on a server with others), and each country you play as results in a different scenario each time.

This game gives you everything you would want in a geopolitical simulator, and more. Choose a country, build alliances (among other treaties), start wars, conquer land, control your economy, military, goverment, and of course, build nukes. While it can be slow to start off, you can even turn countries like Kenya into economical powerhouses with a stacked military. Many reviews make it seem like this is easy to do, and this can be offputting to those looking for a realistic simulator. In reality, it is only easy if you are willing to put your country in billions of dollars of debt and anger every country on Earth, and this will eventually backfire.

Despite all this, the game does have a tricky interface. It's not exactly welcoming to new users, as there is a lot of menus and options to choose from, but this is expected in such a complex game. Of course, as many people complain, this game has its share of bugs, and your screen resolution can cut out most of the battle screen, but this is abosolutely not a reason to overlook this game.

Overall, if you are going to buy this game, I reccomend that you do it with friends, because it makes things much more interesting, but singleplayer is fun as well. For the price of $10, you are easily getting a good deal.

reviewText:
This is a fun game for the time in which it was created. The game finds its most charm in multiplayer where you can freely send nukes over the globe and bomb the hell out of your friends. However, there are a lot of problems that plague having full enjoyment of it otherwise. A lot of things need to be addressed for when SuperPower 3 comes out and I will address some of them here in my review.

First and foremost, there needs to be a much better interface. There are a terms the game wants you to handle in this game that go on unexplained in the National Budget. Things such as inflation, global tax mod, telecommunications, education. Inflation in particular you're told is very bad and you want to keep it around 2%, but you're never told why and there is no visible effects of anything going bad in your economy even if you keep it around 10% for 50 years. Additionally the only way you're given to control it is the interest rate for your economy, which has a negative effect on it. So why would you ever mess with a good thing? The entire interface just needs an improvement altogether. I'd like to know how each bar directly effects the economy.

Secondly, there needs to be popups for important events and a system that allows you to make certain events in the game popups and ignore the rest altogether. For example...I was hanging out as Israel and doing my thing. I had just reannexed the Gaza Strip and everything was going well. And then suddenly, the United States and China had declared war and nukes were flying over the globe. I would have loved to have a popup that would have paused the game in this instance so I could switch to slow-mode and watch the nukes fly and decide for myself after the damage whom to support and who to try to take land from. But as the game sits right now someone can declare war on you and invade your entire nation and you have no notification whatsoever. That's a thing that needs to be improved.

Treaties need to be improved upon. There's not really a way for you to improve the relationships you have with other nations. Eventually if you wait long enough and no great wars are started, the positive effects of the EU and other treaties already in place at the start of the game will bring you to positive relations and will result in world peace. But I should be able to give money to any nation I want to bring relations up. And currently, there's no way to do that. Nations you have bad relations with will always have bad relations with you because they'll carry out hostile actions against you. The only way to fix it is to take em over and annex them, which pisses off the world and makes them do the same thing.

Fourthly, there needs to be a great wikipedia and a company web forum for this game to help with misunderstandings. This has the capacity to be a pretty complex game and people love them and would love to enjoy them. But even now there are things I don't understand like how to do naval bombardments and marine invasions. The game doesn't explain it to me in any way. I'd love to ask on web forums, except none exist. I'd love to check a wikipedia, but the one existing is sorely lacking on almost all subjects. So that needs to be improved.

All in all, SuperPower 2 is not a great Geopolitical Simulator. It's a game that finds its most charm in nuking your friends online as a Wargame. So if you're into that, you'll find a lot of fun in this tame. Go for it!

The game is decent for it's genre even though it's incredibly easy once you get a good economy and lots of research going. Nuking Israel is always fun, though. The game gives you a bit of options regarding laws and systems of government to choose from, these are always nice. Though, I've noticed that there are virtually no real 'right-wing' parties to choose from, I feel as though the political side of this game is heavily biased towards the left. For some reason the official language of Iraq is Kurdish? There may be some other things the developers are biased towards that I have not encountered.

I can live with the things mentioned above especially since I get to ban certain languages, parties, and laws, however, the game is unplayable, it crashes if you nuke a country and it crashes constantly for no particular reason (please note that this may not be experienced by some people). The game has some game-breaking bugs such as not being able to take the capital of some countries because the unit has not been fully deployed and it never will be, you can always get over that by playing LAN and removing the unit from the capital then switching back to your original nation to capture the capital; but the point is that this game should have been released when the bugs/crashes have been looked through and fixed. Evidentally, the developers can't be bothered releasing fixes and as such, do not currently deserve the $10 they're asking for.

I will happily change this review to 'recommend' once the game is playable.

reviewText:
I used to play SuperPower 1 and 2 back in the day, and had fun with both. Having lost both games over time for one reason or another, I decided to purchase Superpower 2 for Steam for nostalgic purposes. What I encountered was a little underwhelming.

As other reviewers have pointed out, realism pretty much flies out the door with this one. One time I played as Croatia and, after an hour of play, had China randomly invade and annex me. In another game I watched online, Italy invaded and annexed China, then started eating up African countries, with no one in the world seemingly caring. I know there are realism mods out there, but as is, the game leaves much to be desired in this regard.

Related to this is how the game's mechanics react to your decisions. Example: I started with a multi-party democracy nation with basic political freedoms, and then - practically overnight - outlawed every religion and language except one, removed freedom of contraception, freedom of speech, freedom of assembly, then transformed the government into a military dictatorship. You know what the drop in popular support was? MAYBE like 5%. I'm not kidding. It went back to normal after a while. Government stability didn't take a hit either. I had done this to see just how insane my nation would go, but discovered that it didn't do anything even negative in the short-term. For a supposed geopolitical simulator, that's a bit lacking.

One of the most aggravating aspects of this game is the economic model. At first glance, it can seem like a wonderful simulation of the world trade, but after trying to figure the thing out...I just can't make a surplus. Well, to be fair, I did once, but I don't even remember how I did it. I've tried various methods, and I've read tutorials online on how to set up your economy, but nothing seems to work. I've dealt with the economic models in other games from a variety of developers, and even if they were at first difficult, I managed to figure them out after a while. SP2, however, has a model that will aggravate the casual gamer and give them headaches, trying to figure out how to keep those numbers from getting red again.

One of the few things I appreciate about this game is the way wars and armies are done. Unlike SP1, which were a bit more clustered and limited to various cities, you can move armies around the map like you could in real life, and let them engage across a wider front. It's fun to see the symbols flying around on the spec-ops-style map, and watch the battles between two sides unfold.

Is SP2 worth purchasing? I honestly don't think it's worth even $10. It can be that one game you take out every year and play for a while, before you remember why you uninstalled it in the first place, but it probably won't be something you play on a regular basis.

reviewText:
EDIT: Initially, I gave this game a negative review. For people who said I didn't play the game enough for a fair review, I purchased the game back in 2001, I have seen plenty of this game.

What changed my mind about the playability of this game was not the developer, who re-released this game for a quick cash grab on steam without fixing major issues, and it wasn't fan boys coming to leave little angry comments about my subjective opinion of their favowite game.

No, it was the 2015 Realism mod. This excellent mod not only updates the game to 2015, but adds the balance, depth and ai common sense I would expect from a game that purports to be an Information-Age global simulation. As such there are a few things to keep in mind:

1. The game allows you to delegate decisions about economic, political, or military matters to the AI. This means the game allows you to get as general or focused as you want without having those other areas fall apart. For those confused by the game I would recommend utilizing and observing the AI behavior and slowly getting more involved.
2. The game (for me at least) has some delay in when it reports feedbackback, particularly involving money. This means that you have to sometimes be a bit patient and wait for changes to register.
3. Single player is merely a primer for what is actually a gigantic united nations simulator community on the multiplayer servers. The real reward for learning this game is to play against more challenging human opponents, but be warned that they take roleplay kind of seriously on most servers.

So in conclusion, the 2015 Realism mod makes this game playable. The game runs stable for me, and seems well optomized. If you like grand strategy titles you should enjoy yourself. Multiplayer is where the real challenge is. If you can't see yourself enjoying geeking out with foreign policy nerds on rp servers, or dealing with some of the learning curve issues, steer clear.

Going to go ahead and say, 9/10 for me.

Lets get started.

Graphics
______
Graphics are not important for this game, but. I am going to say they are pretty damn good. The Globe is amazing looking, in my opinion. There are not really any graphics like you would see in a FPS, or any other RTS games. They just arent needed for this game.
But, with the graphics that are there, 8/10.

Gameplay
_______
This is one of the most advanced Grand Strategies games I have ever played. The ammount of work you need to put into this to learn, is pretty damn high. You have to learn where to put your: Interest Rate to counter deflation, your personal income tax, your global tax mod, your task mod for resources, and much more. This is hard to learn at first, I am still learning of course... But, after 2 hours of playing around with Economics, I pretty much found the sweet spots for China. The military aspect has you: Commanding troops, building troops, building a design out of templates(not that advanced, but still pretty cool) and picking your upgrades. This includes Strategic weapons!. Also, politics are controlled by you. You must: Keep high diplomatic relations with other nations(keeps from being invaded), refrain from using nukes as it causes everyone to hate you(but whats the fun of that :P) and a little more. I like setting AI agressiveness to max...
Overall I think the gameplay aspect gets a 9/10 for me.

Bugs
_____
I couldn't find any bugs, but I only played 2 1/2 hours. I have not played enough to give my humbe opinion on bug status.
?/10

Anyway.
Overall for me is 9/10. Sounds are pretty good to me in this game also.
I would recommend the ♥♥♥♥ out of this game to anyone who loves Grand Strategy Games( Also recommend Victoria II, EU IV, Hearts of Iron series, although these games are not as advanced.) My first full pledged review, so its probably very choppy. Worth the 9$!

reviewText:
I bought the first Super Power when it first came out and loved it. There were a lot of odds and ends that made it rough at times but was playable. Geo-political is my favorite type of game of my strategy list...

If you are looking for a more in-depth strategy game with plenty of complications this one is worth the $10.

I will sy that there are game-ending bugs in SP2 that you almost cannot get around. the worst I have found is enemy units stuck in deployment mode....which means you can't take the territory it is stuck in. If you are looking for conquest victory...this bug ruins it all... I have yet to get around it.

This is a time consuming game....one of those that you leave running while you sleep if things are looking good. Although I liked SP1 better in most of the mechanics... SP2 is still good and has been simplified but with better UI. A combination of both would be epic for me. I would say it is worth the $10. If you live on strategy games this one is a good addition to your collection.
